14.04.2020:
Under the slogan """"Con vos podemos"""", the official campaign was launched to receive financial donations in order to bring humanitarian aid to vulnerable people and families affected by the emergency caused by Covid-19.

The campaign -which will last until April 30- is promoted by the Government of the Republic together with the Costa Rican Banking Association (ABC), the Federation of Savings and Credit Cooperatives (FEDEAC) and kölbi.

This campaign is a public-private alliance so that people can make their financial donation, which will be translated into basic supplies such as food and hygiene kits for vulnerable families.

The inputs will be purchased from national farmers, enterprises and businesses in each community, which will in turn allow the local economy to be reactivated.

The distribution will be in charge of the Municipal Emergency Committees and food will arrive at the beneficiaries' house to avoid crowds.

On Thursday, April 16, Grupo Mutual and Mutual Cartago (MUCAP) joined the “Con vos Podemos” campaign, enabling their accounts so that people can make their donations by electronic transfer or Sinpe Móvil.

The Board of Directors of the Central Bank of Costa Rica (BCCR), in a session held on Monday, April 13, 2020, empowered its Administration to acquire, in the secondary market, holdings from the Ministry of Finance in colones for a maximum amount of ¢ 250,000 million.

The acquisition in the secondary market by the Central Bank of titles of the Ministry of Finance does not constitute financing to the Government, since the purchase of the holdings would be made to a third party, who would be the one who receives the money for the acquisition made by the Central Bank.

Given that this instrument is an exceptional mechanism, the Central Bank restricts its participation to situations of systemic tension, and therefore limits the amount of its intervention and imposes restrictions on the type of holdings that can be acquired and their issue and placement date.

The Central Bank will publish on its website the information on the secondary market transactions carried out under this agreement, at the end of each day in which it carries out said transactions.

16.04.2020:
The Ministry of Science, Technology and Telecommunications (MICITT) makes <U+20B5> 791 million available to finance actions in innovation, science and technology in order to fight COVID-19.

The first call was opened on April 16 and is part of the Innovation and Human Capital for Competitiveness Program (PINN), with the support of the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB).

These are PINN innovation and technology transfer projects to support the health emergency, with an investment of up to <U+20B5> 712 million.

The maximum amount to be awarded per project will be <U+20B5> 142,000,000 and the maximum execution period will be 12 months.

Meanwhile, the Incentive Fund will open a call for an amount of up to <U+20B5> 79 million on May 15 to support research on issues related to COVID-19.

MICITT is promoting three areas of work:

1. Provide resources for research in detection, prevention and treatment of COVID-19

2. Empower the community of national, transnational companies, researchers and national scientists to develop national prototypes

3. Promotion of capacity development in small and medium-sized enterprises to better cope with the economic consequences of COVID-19.

It will be granted on a monthly basis, for the national state of emergency caused by COVID-19, and for a period of up to three months from the first deposit if the circumstances that motivated the granting of the subsidy persist, as long as there are resources  available. The amount is 125.000 colones for the laid off or suspended employees, affected self-employed and informal workers as well as those whose working time has been reduced by more than 50%. The amount of 62.500 colones will be granted to workers  whose working time has been reduced by less than 50%.

description:
Costa Rica, 13.04.2020:
The Ministry of Health recommends that the local Emergency Committees take into account socio-cultural aspects of the Afro-descendant community when communicating recommendations and prevention mesaures against COVID-19. Along these lines, it is recommended, to greatest extent possible, to translate into English the main prevention and information messages such as those regarding hand washing, sneezing, and social isolation.

description:
Ministry of Health seeks to notify sanitary orders digitally
April 16, 2020. 

The Minister of Health, Daniel Salas announced that this afternoon a bill will be sent to the Legislative Assembly that seeks to allow the notification of sanitary orders digitally when there is a threat of a communicable disease of mandatory reporting. The initiative of law was based on the proposal promoted by the deputy María Inés Solís.

description:
Costa Rica, 15.03.2020:
Costa Rica through the Executive Order 42248-MP-S decrees that the request for temporary suspension of the employment contract must be submitted within three days after the day on which the event that gave rise to said request occurred. The decree is effective on March 16th until further notice as a consequence of the intentions to stop the spreading of COVID-19.

description:
Costa Rica, 23.03.2020:
Health authorities also issued a new guideline for repackaging alcohol gel in community pharmacies during the emergency period. This authorizes these establishments to opt for the purchase of larger volume fillings (one gallon or greater), for repackaging in volumes of 60 to 120 ml, as a measure to face shortages.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Businesses
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description:
Costa Rica, 23.03.2020:
The Ministry of Health introduced the guideline for commercial chains, supermarkets and suppliers (mini-super) to guarantee the cleaning of surfaces, implement different schedules for the elderly or people with chronic diseases and label in visible spaces protocols regarding coughing, sneezing and hand washing.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Businesses
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description:
Costa Rica, 01.04.2020:
The Ministry of Health recommends that markets adhere to the following recommendations:
- Informing users about handwashing, sneezing, and coughing protocols.
- Controlling the income of consumers.
- Extending sales hours.
- Disinfect common areas at least once a week.
- Ensuring that cleaning supplies are available.
- There must be a distance of 50 meters between sinks, and there must be 1 sink in the food sales area, all with quality drinking water, soap, disposable hand towels and gel alcohol.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Businesses
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description:
Costa Rica, 03.04.2020:
The Ministry of Health orders a reduction of the maximum capacity of the following business to 50%:
a) establishments for the sale of agricultural inputs,
b) hygiene supply establishments,
c) public or private banking services,
d) funeral homes and/or chapels of vigil,
e) public and private establishments where there is commercialization of agricultural, livestock, fishing and aquaculture products, such as fairs and markets.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Businesses
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description:
Costa Rica, 03.04.2020:
It is resolved to order the temporary closure of all establishments with a sanitary operating permit classified as public meeting places, as of Friday, April 3, 2020 at 5:00 p.m. until Sunday, April 12, at 11:59 p.m. Exceptions: health establishments, public and private establishments where there is commercialization of agricultural, livestock, fishing and aquaculture products, such as fairs and markets etc.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Businesses
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description:
Costa Rica, 13.04.2020:
MS-DM-2658-2020. MINISTERIO DE SALUD:
It is resolved to order the temporary closure of all establishments with a health care operation permit that provide care to the public, on Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays from 7:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. the following day. Likewise, the temporary closure of said establishments on Saturdays and Sundays is ordered in a total manner. These restrictions will apply from 13 April 2020 until 30 April 2020. 
Exceptions: The institutions that, due to the nature of their functions, must remain open, such as the migration, customs and phytosanitary services of the State, land, sea and air border posts, among other essential services.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Businesses
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description:
Costa Rica, 11.04.2020:
The Ministry of Health orders a reduction of the maximum capacity of the following business to 50%:
a) local municipal administrations,
b) establishments for the sale of agricultural and veterinary supplies, and animal food,
c) hygiene supply establishments,
d) public or private banking and financial services,
e) funeral parlors and/or shrines,
f) public and private establishments where there is commercialization of agricultural, livestock, fishing and aquaculture products, such as markets,
These restrictions will apply from 13 April 2020 until 30 April 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Businesses

description:
Costa Rica, 23.03.2020:
The Central Administration is instructed and the Decentralized Administration is urged to establish a basic operating service plan, to guarantee the continuity of the essential tasks in order to ensure the institutional public purpose. For these purposes, institutions may require a maximum attendance of 20% of their total payroll.
The basic operating service plan must include:
a) The application of the teleworking modality in those positions that are possible.
b) The justification of the services that are essential for the operation of the institution.
c) Strict health measures to be applied in the case of workers who must attend in person.

The institutions of the Central Administration must:
a) Apply the telework modality in everything since it is teleworkable.
b) Grant vacations to all those servants who have
accumulated vacation periods.
c) If the servants do not have accumulated periods,
vacation advancement is authorized.

All public servants who are over 65 years of age or have risk factors must be guaranteed with an option to work remotely or take vacation.

type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

Directriz 077-S-MTSS Mideplan:
Addressed to the central and decentralized public administration ""on the functioning of state institutions during the declaration of national emergency by COVID-19"".

The basic operational service plan mentioned above should include
The application of the teleworking modality in those positions that are possible. The justification of the services that are indispensable for the operation of the institution. The strict health measures to be applied in the case of servers who must attend in person.

The application of the teleworking modality in those positions that are possible. The justification of the services that are indispensable for the operation of the institution. The strict health measures to be applied in the case of servers who must attend in person.

Costa Rica, 01.04.2020:
The Ministry of Health recommends that municipal administration and mayors adhere to the following recommendations:
- Placing protocols on handwashing, sneezing, and coughing should be posted in visible places
- Surfaces that are touched continuously should be cleaned frequently.
- Those in charge of cleaning and hygiene must protect themselves with gloves and a mask.
- Specific schedules for older adults are designed.
- There must be a control of the indoor capacity (maximum 50%). 
- There should be supervisory personnel available to verify compliance with these guidelines, both for sellers and buyers.

type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description:
Apr. 1st - In the framework of Holy Week, the Government of Costa Rica reinforces measures to contain the contagion by COVID-19

Measures do not restrict access to basic services. From Friday, April 3 and until Tuesday, April 7, the night vehicle restriction is extended throughout the national territory from 5:00 pm to 5:00 am.
Long-distance public transport will also be restricted and establishments will be closed with sanitary operating permits and attention to face-to-face public, home services are allowed.
Starting Saturday, April 4 and until Tuesday, April 7, the daytime vehicle restriction will apply from 5:00 am to 5:00 pm throughout the country, with license plate distribution.
From Wednesday, April 8 to Sunday, April 12, the movement of vehicles and public transport is restricted, with exceptions.

There is also a total restriction on vehicular traffic with the following exceptions: access to supermarkets, suppliers, grocery stores, pharmacies and health centers, without time restrictions.
type: Restrictions of Mass Gatherings
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event
